name: (E)-2-(4-nitrophenyl)-3-phenylpropenoic acid
Reason: 2-(4-Nitrophenyl)-3-phenylpropenoic acid has a melting point that we will compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings and a nitro group. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. The nitro group introduces a strong dipole moment, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and increase the melting point by approximately +20°C.
